title: Find Dining
short_desc: An online promotion platform for Scarborough restaurants to share their stories.

images.alt: Find Dining logo

title: U-Impactify
short_desc: An online learning and consulting platform targted to Social Organizations.

images.alt: U-Impactify logo

long_desc:
A web-app built by myself with a team of 6 developers. This online learning platform is something akin to the Udemy website, where users can register and select courses offered by our site. Most of the courses are be geared towards skills that would help Social Initiatives improve their operations and activities. In addition to that, users can register as consultants to offer their services to seeking organizations, or create courses for other users to take. Social Initiatives may also post volunteer/employment opportunities on our site as well.

This project was built with Java Spring Boot as the backend framework and ReactJS as the frontend framework. We used a PostgreSQL relational database to store our web app's information. I mainly worked on the backend and built APIs and services for the frontend team to use that would either create, modify, obtain, or remove records from the database.

title: Doodlejump
short_desc: A MIPS coded assembly project that is based the classic Doodlejump game.

images.alt: Start screen of doodlejump game
Instructional guide of doodlejump game
Easy level of doodlejump game
Bombs, boosts, and shields in doodlejump game
End screen of doodlejump game
Medium level of doodlejump game
Shielded doodler in doodlejump game
Hard level of doodlejump game
Doodler close to bomb in doodlejump game

long_desc:
For the final project in my computer organization course, I had to make a game similar to Doodlejump using assembly code. I had to use concepts taught in class and apply them while coding the game, such as registers, memory cache, machine code, and general MIPS programming knowledge.

The most difficult part of making this game is translating logic to assembly code and keeping everything organized. My process for overcoming this is creating flow charts, pseudocode for different parts of my game, and then turning those pseudocode sections into MIPS code. The end result is a simple platform jumping game that is rather enjoyable.

title: Android Shopping App
short_desc: A simple functional shopping app made for Android phones.

images.alt: Login of android app
Store display of android app
Customer's shopping cart of android app
Checkout screen of android app
Admin screen of android app
Employee screen of android app
Restock screen of android app

long_desc:
At the end of my second-year fall semester, my software design course had us develop an Android app for our culminating project. This was first time I ever worked in a scrum team. Using Android Studio and all the Java skills and design patterns taught in class, my team and I managed to create a working shop app that allowed customers to buy items, employees to restock items, and admins to view activity history. Those are just some of the many features we implemented in this app.

For this app, I had to learn Android Studio and how to apply the MVC model while making different app components. From retrieving data from the SQLite database, to reading data from the database and displaying it with a beautiful UI. Also at the beginning of the project, my team and I decided to use my prototype solution as the starting point of our app. Since it was the cleanest and most-finished out of all of ours.

title: Mood
short_desc: A sentiment analysis web app that will generate films, music, and gifs according to your mood.

images.alt: Landing page of mood web app
Results page of a surprised mood
Full results page of a fearful mood

long_desc:
I attended the Hack Western 6 hackathon in winter 2019. There, I and a team of four people (myself included), worked on a web app that was able to detect one's current mood, and would generate an endless list of movies and gifs, and select one song, that would help this person with how they're feeling. We made this using various APIs for getting the desired movies, gifs, and songs. Javascript and nodejs for backend purposes. Bootstrap, HTML, and CSS for making the frontend. And we built a custom API that allows us to communicate between backend and frontend.

This was by far, the biggest project I've worked on at a hackathon. It proves to me that with a clear end goal and strong dedication, things can be done in a limited amount of time. I had a lot of fun attending this hackathon and learned a lot of skills that proved to be helpful during my co-op term at UTSC the Bridge.

title: Old Portfolio Website
short_desc: The previous website I created to present my skills, projects, and work experience

images.alt: Landing page of old portfolio website

long_desc:
While job-searching for my first co-op term, I decided to update my portfolio website. The last time I ever touched it was in my senior year of high school. Now that I'm a university student studying computer science, I decided to make my website reflect that fact. This was made using pure HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, with the AOS CSS library for animations. This was also the first time I ever used flex layouts, so I took full advantage of their responsiveness and put more effort into making my site more mobile-friendly.

This site is still up and running, but I will no longer update there anymore. Since I have a newer site (this one you're currently on) to represent my portfolio.

title: Heir to the Throne
short_desc: A point-&-click adventure game made using JavaScript, sessionStorage, and HTML/CSS.

images.alt: Opening page of Heir to the Throne
Location choice page of Heir to the Throne
Clue on mirror of a room
Clue on broken mirror of a room
Page displaying profile of the royal children and clues gathered
Secret area in barracks room of game
Secret room where heir is revealed
Secret area in dungeon room of game
Quick time events of dungeon room
Successful quick time events of dungeon room
Secret room where outsider is revealed
Arresting the outsider
Good ending of the game
Being offered water by the outsider
Ending where you get poisoned by the outsider
Ending where you arrest the heir to the throne

long_desc:
One of my earliest computer-programming projects was Heir to the Throne. This is first game I created using JavaScript, HTML, and CSS and I created it during grade 11 high school. I was a huge video game nerd and always dreamed of one day developing my own game or working for a large game company.

This game is a point-and-click adventure game where the player can explore many locations on a map by clicking on its image. The purpose of this game is to find out the traitor among the King's children and arrest them before they either kill the player or the true heir to the throne. In certain areas, there are clues that pertain to the traitor's or the heir's identity and the player can cross-reference those clues to each of the King's children's profiles. The player wins if they arrest the traitor and loses if they arrest the true heir or gets killed by the traitor.
